awd_titl_txt: Neural Mechanisms underlying Evolvability of Behavior
awd_abstract_narration:
This project examines fundamental questions about the features of neural circuits that affect the evolution of behavior. The species being examined are nudibranch sea slugs, which have highly accessible nervous systems that allow experiments to be conducted that are not feasible in other types of animals. The brains of nudibranchs contain only about 10,000 nerve cells (neurons), many of which can be individually identified from animal to animal within a species. Furthermore, neurons can often be identified across different species. Electrical activity can be recorded from multiple neurons to reveal neural circuitry. The connectivity of those circuits can be compared across species. This research team found that although the species have the same sets of neurons, they are wired up differently, even when the species produce similar behaviors. One goal of the project is to artificially rewire the neurons in one species to produce the neural circuit of another species and to create mathematical models that do the same. This will establish how easy it is to convert the behavior of one species into that of another. It also contributes to understanding the basic rules for generating behavior by comparing across species instead of focusing on a single species. The project engages the public by soliciting observations of nudibranch behavior from divers around the world through social media. It also provides important research opportunities to under-represented students through a research pipeline and creates resources that will be available to the scientific community to aid in identifying neurons and mapping out circuits.

Evolvability reflects the ability to evolve. This project examines the features of neural circuits that affect the evolvability of swimming behaviors in nudibranchs. The project uses a variety of techniques to achieve its goals. First, transcriptomics is used to resolve the phylogeny of the Nudibranchia and allow phylogenic hypotheses to be tested. The brain transcriptomes further aid in the discovery of molecular markers for identified neurons, which are needed particularly in species that do not swim.  Electrophysiological techniques are used to search for "latent" circuitry, that is, connectivity that might be present in non-swimmers and potentially activated by small changes. These changes will be applied using the dynamic clamp technique to inject artificial synaptic and membrane conductances and through ectopic expression of serotonin receptors. Finally, mathematical simulations are used to examine the consequences of different circuit architectures and their robustness for rhythmic activity.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was to investigate the neural mechanisms underlying the evolution of neural circuits and behavior. The project, focused on the neurons and connectivity underlying rhythmic swimming behaviors in sea slugs. The neurons controlling these behaviors are individually identifiable from animal to animal within a species and even across species, allowing the neural mechanisms to be compared. The major finding was that the same neuron in different species can play a fundamentally different role in the production of behavior. This was true when the behaviors themselves had diverged, but it was also true even when the behavior was conserved. Thus, although the neurons themselves were conserved and the behavior was conserved, the neural connectivity had diverged. In fact, we found that synaptic connectivity was one of the most highly divergent properties of the neuronal circuits. 

We discovered that the same (homologous) neuron in different species can express different complements of serotonin receptor subtypes. These differences in gene expression could provide a mechanism by which evolutionary forces changed the functioning of neurons. In one species, we found differences in gene expression even correlated with the propensity of the individual animal to produce the behavior, suggesting that control of gene expression in individual neurons underlies behavioral flexibility.

The neural dynamics underlying the production of rhythmic activity was examined computationally in two ways. First, the synaptic connections between the biological neurons were pharmacologically blocked and then replaced with computer-generated synapses mediated by microelectrodes. In this way, the circuit was disabled and then rescued. The connectivity of one species was then imposed upon the biological neurons of another species to show that same neurons could produce a rhythmic output using the neural mechanism of another species. This research shows a biological instantiation of the theoretical concept that there are multiple neural solutions for the production of behavior.

The second computational approach was to mathematically model the neurons. A key finding of the biological study was that none of the neurons on their own produced oscillatory activity; the rhythmicity arose through the interactions of the neurons. The mathematical models uncovered the importance of matching synaptic kinetics and firing rates as well as the need for particular membrane properties to maintain robust and stable activity.

The model inspired additional electrophysiological investigating of the neural circuits. We found in one species that the generation of rhythmic activity was caused by only two bilateral pairs of neurons that each had complementary membrane properties and synaptic actions. Thus, although none of the neurons on its own could produce robust rhythmic activity, the combination of the properties of these neurons could. 

To calibrate biologically-plausible models of neurons and synapses, we developed a new computational approach that was able to match experimental sampling rates and simulate biological temporal characteristics. We also developed a computational toolkit that is available for other modelers to use, which was one of the broader impacts.

The project had major impact on undergraduate and graduate education at Georgia State University, which has Title II and Title V designations from the US Department of Education, denoting the university as a Primarily Black Institution (PBI). The project also was very prolific producing over 45 peer-reviewed papers and several more in preparation.
